utterances: Unidentified Woman #3: And I got some dish towels recently that I'm going to regift at Christmas with baked goods.
Unidentified Man #2: Well, she'll take cards that people have attached onto a Christmas or birthday present, and then generally, she'll cross off the name and then write somebody else's name onto it.
Unidentified Man #3: Boxes of chocolates, colored pencils, the works.
Unidentified Woman #4: It's like a little baby outfit.
Unidentified Woman #1: What is your intention?
Is it just to get rid of something that you absolutely don't want?
Or is it something you really like, can't use, have no use for that you can genuinely give?
Unidentified Man #4: In Christmas of 2006, one of our lovely members here at the YMCA gave my cousin Chris some earrings, and he passed them off to our business manager.
And then she gave them to me the day before yesterday and recommended that I give them to my girlfriend, and I don't have a girlfriend, all the ladies out there.
Unidentified Woman #5: I think that would suck.
Unidentified Woman #1: I think our culture, we're just not taking the time to get to know our family and our friends, to what I really think you might want.
Unidentified Woman #6: Because I gave it to you with all my heart, and then you give it to somebody else.
Do you know anybody who'd been busted doing that?
Unidentified Man #5: My dad.
Unidentified Woman #6: One of my friends.
Unidentified Woman #1: I do know a girl who received a gift from a nun.
And she gave that gift to her sister.
And then I was at the party where the sister returned it to the nun.
True story.
In terms of the etiquette of it, is it proper etiquette?
Unidentified Man #2: You know what?
I do kind of think it's tacky.
Unidentified Woman #1: I personally think that it is a very functional thing, especially in this economy.
Unidentified Man #3: I am not as embarrassed as I would be if I didn't have a gift ready when I received one.
I feel like it's far better to be prepared in these type of situations.
Unidentified Woman #7: I think we all might - all be receiving regifts this year.
So, if you're lucky enough to get presents this year, may they be exactly what you wished for, even if it came from Aunt Susie's boss's cousin's friend's sister.
That was independent producer Vanessa Romo.
She spoke with Don DeGrute(ph), Mario Alvarado(ph), Alex Becker(ph), Martha Cordova(ph), and Lawrence Epps(ph).
This coming week marks a year since 17 students and staff were shot to death at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.
Seventeen people were also injured.
Witnesses identified a former student as the gunman.
He's been charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder.
The shooting sparked grief and outrage across the nation and galvanized many in Parkland to organize, to rally and to speak out against gun violence.
The Parkland students, as they have become known, have been active in the ""March For Our Lives"" rally in Washington, D.C., and in rallies and activities across the country.
Two leaders of that movement are now in our studios, Matt Deitsch and Charlie Mirsky.
Thanks both very much for being with us.
Thank you so much for having us.
Thank you.
Matt, you're a graduate now of Marjory Stoneman Douglas.
I gather you have siblings who are still there.
What's the last year been like?
Well, I graduated in 2016, and I was really involved in clubs at the school.
I was senior class vice president.
I knew people of all grades.
And so I was home when everything was happening.
And on February 14, that evening, I mean, we were supposed to have a birthday party for my sister, and some of her friends didn't make it out of the school.
And the reality is that in that moment, I felt absolutely helpless.
And my sister was sad, my brother was angry and I didn't know what to do.
And it wasn't until we started going to funerals and vigils where something clicked in me and I said I was going to start working.
And so the last year has been effective, and we've been mobilizing young people.
We've been inspiring the nation.
And we've been shedding light on the reality of gun violence.
And that's the real difference that we're trying to communicate to people is, like, it's not okay to just react.
You need to activate yourself because if we're not standing up and organizing ourselves, then we're not doing enough to save lives in America.
Charlie Mirsky, you attended Spanish River High School, which I gather is quite close, right?
Yeah, it's just a couple miles away.
What was the day like a year ago?
So the whole experience was very different for me because I was not aware immediately that everything was going on.
I heard rumors about certain things, but when this stuff happens in your community, I assumed it wasn't true.
I thought this kind of stuff doesn't happen to us.
This kind of stuff doesn't happen here.
And in my mind, statistically, I didn't even think it happened, really, anywhere.
So to find out that it was true that my friend's school was shot up and that a previous teacher of mine, Scott Beigel, was, in fact, killed in that shooting, that was really shocking for me.
And that - I wasn't immediately involved.
I didn't think - the moment it happened, I wasn't immediately thinking, I'm going to go into this and make this stuff happen and change these laws.
But ""March For Our Lives"" - we just realized, like, if we work together, we can really make something happen.
I'm Farai Chideya and this is News & Notes.
Time now for our Africa Update.
We begin in Zimbabwe.
I, Robert Gabriel Mugabe, do swear that I will well and truly serve Zimbabwe in the Office of President, so help me God.

In a lot of different ways, both of you have learned over the past year that it would be hard to think of a more divisive issue in America than guns, gun rights, gun registration, gun ownership - divisive, emotional, important to a lot of people on all sides.
Are there one or two areas where you can see most people agreeing across party or ideological lines?
Yeah, there's a bill introduced by Mike Thompson and Peter King.
It's a bipartisan bill, 10 original co-sponsors - five Democrats and five Republicans.
It's universal background checks, which is approved by 97 percent of Americans.
Also, another topic would be working on digitizing ATF records, helping law enforcement enforce the laws that already exist.
And that's Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
That's right.
If there are measures that law enforcement needs to enact so that they can keep American families safe, and they can't do that if they aren't given the proper resources or means to do so.

Have you, over this past year, not encountered anyone who would say to either of you, look; I mean, I don't want anyone to be hurt or killed, but I do feel safer if I have free access to a gun because I live in a rough neighborhood, and life can be rough, and that's my home security system?
I can't wait five minutes for the police to arrive.
Yeah.
And every single one of our policies supports your right to do that.

That's the thing is like, when we're talking about what we actually need to fight to prevent gun violence, while you are statistically less safe with a gun than without a gun, that may not work on - to convince many Americans, and that's OK.
Well, you know, just telling them the statistics won't make somebody feel safe.
Yeah, of course, because, I mean, that's a very emotional choice.
And you're - like, you have the right to make that choice.
So when we have those conversations, I usually tie it into - Parkland was one of the safest cities in Florida.
It was voted that for almost a decade.
Thousand Oaks was a top-five safest city in America.
This can happen anywhere.
I think I have one last question for both of you.
Are there times when you'd like to get back to being a kid?
I mean, in some ways, we still are kids.
Like, we'll still go out sometimes late at night and, you know, go to the bowling alley or go see movies or whatnot.
There are times where we just want to lay down and do nothing.
But on February 14, we made that commitment to do this work, and we haven't faltered at all.

Obviously, I'd trade anything to go back to February 13 and not have experienced that trauma, not seen what my sister went through and what the community went through and what all these families have gone through.

And - but that's why we do this work, and that's why we're out here every single day, every single night, working as hard as we possibly can because every day, there's more families that are feeling like that in America, and our country's better than that.

I want every single person that's experienced gun violence today to be some of the last people experiencing gun violence in America because this trauma is deep, and it has to be acknowledged, and we have to be actively trying to prevent this trauma.
Matt Deitsch and Charlie Mirsky are a couple of organizers of the ""March For Our Lives."" Thanks very much for being with us.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
